subject: Re: NBC English - oh, and Hi everyone
msgSnippet: ... people write it and have their unique connections to the letters. Shavian Script is best printed as it is quite clear. Moreover, the letters cover all the
messageBody:
--- Sid wrote:

> QuikSkript can be more difficult to read, especially when other
people write it and have their unique connections to the letters.
Shavian Script is best printed as it is quite clear. Moreover, the
letters cover all the sounds of the English alphabet whereas in
QuikSkript there is some fudging. You cannot write as fast in
Shavian Script

- - -

SB: "Connections" has two interpretations: symbol sound connections
and the connections between letters. Which were you referring to?

If it is the latter, there should be no unique cursive connections.
There are some ligatures but how to form these is well described.
For the most part, this is a linear script with no connections
between symbols.

- - -

SB: QS merges some phonemes but I would not call this "fudging".
All orthographers whose goal is communication rather than a detailed
description of a dialect or accent engage in it to a greater or
lesser degree.

SB: Shavian was designed to be handwritten. Read noted that some
people had difficult with some of the shapes so ten years later he
revised it. He simplified some of the shapes and removed others.

Here is a side by side comparison that was originally prepared by
Read's daughter for a display at the University of Reading [UK]:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/saundspel/files/Shaw-
Alphabet/readscripts.gif


Steve

--- Sid wrote:

> QuikSkript can be more difficult to read, especially when other 
people write it and have their unique connections to the letters. 
Shavian Script is best printed as it is quite clear. Moreover, the 
letters cover all the sounds of the English alphabet whereas in 
QuikSkript there is some fudging. You cannot write as fast in 
Shavian Script

                             - - -

SB: "Connections" has two interpretations:  symbol sound connections 
and the connections between letters.  Which were you referring to?

If it is the latter, there should be no unique cursive connections. 
There are some ligatures but how to form these is well described. 
For the most part, this is a linear script with no connections 
between symbols.

                             - - -

SB:  QS merges some phonemes but I would not call this "fudging". 
All orthographers whose goal is communication rather than a detailed 
description of a dialect or accent engage in it to a greater or 
lesser degree.  

SB:  Shavian was designed to be handwritten. Read noted that some 
people had difficult with some of the shapes so ten years later he 
revised it.  He simplified some of the shapes and removed others.  

Here is a side by side comparison that was originally prepared by 
Read's daughter for a display at the University of Reading [UK]:

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/saundspel/files/Shaw-
Alphabet/readscripts.gif

  
Steve
